Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Subsubsection: Mauwake as a Trans New Guinea language
Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{basic}} \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{order of clausal constituents}} is verb-final. In neutral clauses with both subject and object the order is \textsc{sov} \REF{ex:1:x656}, but it changes into \textsc{osv} when the object is fronted \REF{ex:1:x657} as a theme (\sectref{sec:9.1}). Adverbials are somewhat less constrained in their ordering. It is also very common to have a verb as the only element in a clause \REF{ex:1:x659}.
Content 1: \gll Ona emeria nain=ke\textsubscript{S} maa\textsubscript{O} wafur-a-k. | \gls 3s.GEN woman that1=CF thing throw-PA-3s | \glt  `His wife threw things.'
Content 2: \gll Wiipa nain\textsubscript{O} eka=ke\textsubscript{S} mu-o-k. | \gls daughter that1 water=CF swallow-PA-3s | \glt  `The daughter was swallowed by the water.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Subsubsection: Mauwake as a Trans New Guinea language
Knowledge Point: Mauwake is clearly a nominative-accusative type language, rather than ergative-\linebreak absolutive. The agent of a transitive verb \REF{ex:1:x1523} is marked in the same way as the actor of an intransitive verb \REF{ex:1:x1524}, and most experiential verbs have the experiencer as a nominative subject \REF{ex:1:x1525}.
Content 1: \gll Yo mauw-owa nia asip-i-yem. | \gls 1s.UNM work-NMZ 2p.ACC help-NP-PR.1s | \glt  `I help you with work.'
Content 2: \gll Yo koka=pa ik-e-m. | \gls 1s.UNM jungle=LOC be-PA-1s | \glt  `I was in the jungle.'
Content 3: \gll Yo wuailal-i-yem a. | \gls 1s.UNM hunger-NP-PR.1s oh | \glt  `Oh, I'm hungry.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Subsubsection: Mauwake as a Trans New Guinea language
Knowledge Point: \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{Verb morphology}} in Mauwake is extensive, even if not as extensive and complex as in some other Papuan languages. The morphology is agglutinative, and affixation is mostly very transparent. Suffixes are used for subject, tense and aspect, benefactive, distributive, causative and counterfactual marking. Prefixing is used very little, only for reduplication and to form verbs referring to bringing and taking. It is possible to have several derivational and inflectional affixes in one verb, as shown by the elicited example \REF{ex:1:x664}, but in actual usage this is rare.
Content 1: \gll Muuka wia \textbf{arim-ow-omak-om-ek-a-k}. | \gls son 3p.ACC grow-CAUS-DISTR/PL-BEN-BNFY1.\TEXTSC{CNTF-pa}-3s | \glt  `(S)he would have brought up (many) sons for me.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Subsubsection: Mauwake as a Trans New Guinea language
Knowledge Point: A very typical feature in Papuan languages is a difference between final (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.4}) and medial verbs (\sectref{sec:3.8.3.5}). The former are finite verbs with full inflection for tense and subject number and person, and the most typical position for them is at the end of a declarative sentence. The medial verbs indicate whether the subject of a clause is the same as \REF{ex:1:x662}, or different from \REF{ex:1:x663}, that of the following clause. The same-subject forms also indicate whether the action of the second verb is simultaneous with that of the first verb, or sequential \REF{ex:1:x662} in relation to it. Medial clauses (\sectref{sec:8.2}) are coordinate with, but also dependent on, the following clause. Because of the existence and extensive use of medial clauses, temporal subordinate clauses (\sectref{sec:8.3.3.1}) are used very little in Mauwake.\footnote{Medial clauses in Papuan languages are often translated with temporal subordinate clauses in other languages, even if they are not subordinate in the original language.}
Content 1: \gll Owowa or-\textbf{op}, wuailal-\textbf{ep} akia ik-e-k. | \gls village go-SS.SEQ be.hungry-SS.SEQ banana roast-PA-3s | \glt  `He went to the village, was hungry and roasted bananas.'
Content 2: \gll Mik-\textbf{amkun} me um-o-k, wiowa onaiya ikiw-em-ik-\textbf{eya}. Olas=ke war-e-k. | \gls spear-1s/p.DS not die-PA-3s spear with go-SS.SIM-be-2/3s.DS Olas=CF kill-PA-3s | \glt `When I speared it, it didn't die, (but) as it was going with the spear Olas killed it.'
Content 3: \gll Owowa or-\textbf{op}, wuailal-\textbf{ep} akia ik-e-k. | \gls village go-SS.SEQ be.hungry-SS.SEQ banana roast-PA-3s | \glt  `He went to the village, was hungry and roasted bananas.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Subsubsection: Mauwake as a Trans New Guinea language
Knowledge Point: The \textstyleEmphasizedWords{{noun phrase}} (\sectref{sec:4.1}) most commonly consists of the head noun by itself, or with just one modifier. In a noun phrase a pluralizing \REF{ex:1:x658} unmarked pronoun, a possessive noun phrase, a temporal phrase, or a qualifier noun phrase may precede the head noun; all the other modifiers follow it. A possessive preceding the head noun and an adjective following it \REF{ex:1:x660} is quite common in Trans New Guinea languages \citep[19]{Reesink1987}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{wi} \textbf{emeria} teeria nain | \gls 3p.UNM woman group that1 | \glt  `that group of women'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{yena} aamun \textbf{gelemuta} kuisow | \gls 1s.GEN 1s/p.younger.sibling small one | \glt `my one younger brother' or `one of my younger brothers'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Concerning the following sentence level features Mauwake shows itself a typical \textsc{ov} language. The interrogative marker \textstyleStyleVernacularWordsItalic{-i} always occurs sentence-finally in polar questions \REF{ex:1:x672} (\sectref{sec:7.2.2}).
Content 1: \gll Yo emeria efar uruf-a-man=\textbf{i}? | \gls 1s.UNM woman 1s.DAT see-PA-2p=QM | \glt `Did you see my wife?'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: In non-polar, or content questions (\sectref{sec:7.2.1}), the question word or phrase is in the same position that would be occupied by the non-interrogative word or phrase in a statement~\REF{ex:1:x673}.
Content 1: \gll Ni sira \textbf{kamenap} on-a-man? | \gls 2p.UNM custom what.like do-PA-2p | \glt `What did you do?'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: In complex sentences (\sectref{sec:8.3}), the subordinate clause usually comes before the main clause \REF{ex:1:x674}.
Content 1: \gll Mua imen-ap=\textbf{na} feeke wia p-ekap-eka. | \gls man find-SS.SEQ=TP here.CF 3p.ACC BPX-come-IMP.2p | \glt `If you find the men, bring them here.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Complement clauses (\sectref{sec:8.3.2}) behave like other subordinate clauses, preceding the main clause \REF{ex:1:x675}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mukuna} \textbf{kerer-e-k} \textbf{nain} i me paayar-e-mik. | \gls fire start-PA-3s that1 1p.UNM not understand-PA-1/3p | \glt `We didn't realise that a fire had started.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: The typical \textsc{ov} order for predicate-copula applies only partly in Mauwake, as a copular verb is not used for for the present tense. The \textsc{ov} order does show in the other tenses and the medial forms \REF{ex:1:x676}.

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Clause and sentence level features that correlate with the \textsc{ov} order are as follows. The position of a complementizer or a subordinator is clause-final \REF{ex:1:x677}.

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Both manner adverbs, postpositional phrases, and non-argument noun phrases precede the verb \REF{ex:1:x678}.
Content 1: \gll Fikera nain \textbf{sira} \textbf{feenap} on-a-mik. | \gls kunai.grass that1 custom like.this do-PA-1/3p | \glt  `This is what they did to the \textstyleForeignWords{kunai} grass.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Typical \textsc{ov} features also manifest themselves in different phrases. In the \textsc{vp}s (or verbal groups, as they are called below in \sectref{sec:3.8.5.1}), the main verb precedes the auxiliary \REF{ex:1:x679}.
Content 1: \gll Saa=iw \textbf{ir-am-ika-i-mik}. | \gls sand=INST come-SS.SIM-be-NP-PR.1/3p | \glt `They are coming along the sand/beach.'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: In basic noun phrases (\sectref{sec:4.1.1}) the genitive precedes the head noun \REF{ex:1:x680}:

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: Mauwake has postpositional phrases (\textsc{pp}), rather than prepositional phrases \REF{ex:1:x681}.
Content 1: \gll koor(a) kuenuma=pa | \gls house underside=LOC | \glt `underneath the house'

Subsection: Typological overview of morphological and syntactic features
Knowledge Point: An \textsc{ov} feature that shows on word level in Mauwake is that verbs have suffixes rather than prefixes \REF{ex:1:x682}.
Content 1: \gll Akia ik-\textbf{omak-e-mik}. | \gls banana roast-DISTR/PL-PA-1/3p | \glt `We roasted many bananas.'
